questions.question:
After stacking the DNSCache artifacts, which two domains stand out as the most rare and worthy of further investigation?

Answer format: domain1, domain2.
questions.hint: An analysis script that can stack DNSCache output should be able to surface the rare (least frequent) DNS lookups in the dataset.

questions.question: Which workstation were the cached entries identified in the previous question observed on?
questions.hint: The Select-String cmdlet can be used to finds text (like a domain name) within files.

questions.question:
After stacking process names across the environment, which two rare executables stand out as suspicious?

Answer format: name1, name2.
questions.hint: When stacking processes, the most common Windows executables will sink to the bottom of the suspicion list. Focus on the processes with very low counts, especially those with unusual or random-looking names.

questions.question: What directory were the two suspicious processes located in?
questions.hint: Try using an analysis script to stack process paths instead of just names. Most legitimate Windows executables live in C:\Windows\System32 or under C:\Program Files, so any rare entries running from a non-standard location should draw attention.

questions.question: Submit the MD5 hashes to VirusTotal. What popular threat label is assigned to the specific executable that uses RemCom for remote execution?
questions.hint:
Determine the MD5 hashes of the previously identified binaries using the raw CSV output or the Get-ProcsWMICLIMD5Stack.ps1 script from Kansa. From there, look up these hashes on a malware database like VirusTotal and check the Popular threat label value.

Bonus: Read up on RemCom and how tools like Impacket's PsExec leverage it for remote command execution.

questions.question: What IP address did one of the systems establish a suspicious network connection with?
questions.hint: You might need to create a custom Netstat stacking script to aggregate established network connections by process across the environment. From the rarest entries, identify the remote IP address that the suspicious process communicated with.

questions.question: Which rare Prefetch entry represents an executable that appears legitimate by name but does not exist in a normal Windows system?
questions.hint: Look for rare Prefetch entries that don't match known Windows executables. Cross-reference the name with a known-good system or research it online. This is a good example of an Ambiguous Identifier anomaly.
